Among several ways to influence the result of a question asked in a poll, there is contextualizing. There are monothematic polls with a single question in focus - there is no context to take care of in these. Whenever there are one or more additional questions asked in a poll, there is a possible interference between the answers of the single questions, I guess. Convictions in the one question may trigger a certain mindset and subconscious reaction that leads to approval or rejection of the other question. Asked in separate monothematic polls the second answer could possibly look differently. I guess this is what happened in the Emerson College poll, although I don't want to insinuate intention.
